We're just maybe doing it to prove that we're a superpower in the world. 
I just think the initial motives were questionable, related to George Bush's father's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 
If the original intention was to give democracy to a country without a fair political system, I think that would be a fair motivation, but if there were personal issues involved, I don't think it would be fair. 
But I think it's been dragged out for too long. 
If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose and a good reason for the war. 
However, I don't think our reasons have been deteriorated and misconceived over time. 
It seems like we're still at war just for the sake of war, and we don't want to end this thing without a decisive victory or conclusion. 
I think it's gone on long enough, and it should stop. 
Their government and officials will have to fend for themselves eventually. 
I think that time has come. 
We've been draining our economy for a long time, spending billions of dollars, while we have our own wars, such as poverty and other issues, that we should be addressing. 
I think it's a heavy burden on our economy, as the purpose has been stretched to absurdity. 
They're spending billions and billions of dollars. 
War shouldn't be in our long-term budget. 
There are obviously issues like poverty, internal improvements, public roads, schools, etc. 
We have a lot of problems that need to be solved, such as healthcare, which I think could be better spent on. 
Right now, that money is being spent to have some of our citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we've lost the reason for.

I'd like to clarify one thing, but I'm not sure if it's relevant. It's just that someone was online and they found out some stuff. I don't think it's an invasion of privacy, but on sites like Myspace, if you post information online, it's basically public. And on Myspace, if you want to see someone's profile, you have to be their friend or have someone else be your friend so that you can see it. So, if you're friends with someone, you've given them permission to see your profile. So, when you put information online, you have to know that a lot of people are going to see that. And I think it's actually good that someone saw that and was able to prevent a life from being lost.

It's tough because you can't have someone just sitting around all day looking at everyone's profiles to prevent something bad from happening. But then it becomes some kind of discrimination if they're only looking at the bad kids. I don't think it's right to have someone's job be to look at people's profiles. But it all depends on the situation - maybe they were just randomly browsing and happened to see it, or maybe they were actually looking for evidence of something. So, I'm not really sure.

Well, like, I don't have a Myspace, but I have a Facebook. I know there are creepy people out there who can see things about me, and I saw a news report about a guy who was trying to show how easy it was to get information online. He went onto someone's profile and got their screen name right away, and then talked to them on instant messenger and got them to meet him in under a minute. I personally wouldn't agree to meet someone I didn't know, but I've had people in my class who I don't recognize their screen names, but they IM me and they know it's me. It's hard because you think they know your interests, they know what you look like, and sometimes if you post your class schedule, they know where you are during the day, who your friends are, and they know a lot about you, including photos. I try to limit what I post, but at the same time, the whole point of having one is to be able to communicate with my friends, so I don't want to limit it too much. It's a tricky issue because I only accept people I know, but you never really know who can see what.

Uh, yeah, I've heard that my roommate was telling me that in her high school, there was an issue about students being banned from having Myspace. That seemed a little weird to me, and I wasn't sure how school officials had the right to tell their students they couldn't have Myspace. I'm not even sure if that's a privacy issue, but I don't really know how they had the right to do that.

That's the only other thought I have.

Yes.

Hmm, we only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. We feel that there's still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States. I think it's not just a women's issue. Different fields of work have different levels of gender discrimination. I feel that women face more difficulties in many areas. For example, even in a society that strives for equality, many people find it hard to accept women as their superiors. This is because society's attitude towards women has been shaped over time. If a woman has the qualifications for a certain position, but her superiors still won't promote her due to a historical lack of women in top business positions, that's a problem. The same thing happens to men, especially in industries like fashion. Generally, men don't stay home to take care of the kids, and society mocks this choice. People think that men should be the primary breadwinner, not stay home to take care of the kids. However, in some cases, it's the opposite – the wife has a better job, and the husband stays home to take care of the kids, yet society still mocks this choice.

In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously. They think that if a man is into fashion, he's somehow different from women. They assume that men who are into fashion must have different tastes or lifestyles, and that they can't truly understand women's needs. They think that other men are different, and that they can't possibly understand women's needs. This is why people are discriminated against based on where they're from or their gender. Changing this is difficult because society has formed its own set of stereotypes. We've made a lot of progress, especially with women rising to top business positions and becoming CEOs, but change is slow. If we continue at our current pace, women will keep rising to the top, and people will start to accept this. Similarly, men staying home to take care of the kids is becoming more accepted because people are starting to realize that women might have better jobs. People in the fashion industry are also starting to realize that people's needs might not be what they think they are. So, we need to promote the qualities of people who are often discriminated against without being too pushy. If you try to force it, people will resist. If we're doing everything we can already, we don't need to do anything else because if we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. We've made a lot of progress, and change takes time.

It's also possible that our society will discriminate against you because of where you're from or your gender. For example, if you're from a rural area and your grammar isn't great, but you're extremely intelligent, and you work your way up to be a CEO, other men might look down on you and think, "How do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put together a sentence?" Or if you're intelligent but your grammar isn't great, other men might look down on you. So, our society might discriminate against you because of your gender and where you're from.

I would say yes because many of the things they do are very traditional, like they've been doing the same things for a long time. If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. 
I don't think you should disagree with the state's decision to legalize gay marriage, as you chose to live there.

I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I believe it should be legalized based on each state's discretion.

We feel that there's still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States. I think it's not just a women's issue. Different fields of work have different levels of gender discrimination. I feel that women face more difficulties in many areas. For example, even in a society that strives for equality, many people find it hard to accept women as their superiors. This is because society's attitude towards women has been shaped over time. If a woman has the qualifications for a certain position, but her superiors still won't promote her due to a historical lack of women in top business positions, that's a problem. The same thing happens to men, especially in industries like fashion. Generally, men don't stay home to take care of the kids, and society mocks this choice. People think that men should be the primary breadwinner, not stay home to take care of the kids. However, in some cases, it's the opposite – the wife has a better job, and the husband stays home to take care of the kids, yet society still mocks this choice.

In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously. They think that if a man is into fashion, he's somehow different from women. They assume that men who are into fashion must have different tastes or lifestyles, and that they can't truly understand women's needs. They think that other men are different, and that they can't possibly understand women's needs. This is why people are discriminated against based on where they're from or their gender. Changing this is difficult because society has formed its own set of stereotypes. We've made a lot of progress, especially with women rising to top business positions and becoming CEOs, but change is slow. If we continue at our current pace, women will keep rising to the top, and people will start to accept this. Similarly, men staying home to take care of the kids is becoming more accepted because people are starting to realize that women might have better jobs. People in the fashion industry are also starting to realize that people's needs might not be what they think they are. So, we need to promote the qualities of people who are often discriminated against without being too pushy. If you try to force it, people will resist. If we're doing everything we can already, we don't need to do anything else because if we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. We've made a lot of progress, and change takes time.

It's also possible that our society will discriminate against you because of where you're from or your gender. For example, if you're from a rural area and your grammar isn't great, but you're extremely intelligent, and you work your way up to be a CEO, other men might look down on you and think, "How do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put together a sentence?" Or if you're intelligent but your grammar isn't great, other men might look down on you. So, our society might discriminate against you because of your gender and where you're from.

We feel that there's still a problem of gender discrimination in the United States. I think it's not just a women's issue. Different fields of work have different levels of gender discrimination. I feel that women face more difficulties in many areas. For example, even in a society that strives for equality, many people find it hard to accept women as their superiors. This is because society's attitude towards women has been shaped over time. If a woman has the qualifications for a certain position, but her superiors still won't promote her due to a historical lack of women in top business positions, that's a problem. The same thing happens to men, especially in industries like fashion. Generally, men don't stay home to take care of the kids, and society mocks this choice. People think that men should be the primary breadwinner, not stay home to take care of the kids. However, in some cases, it's the opposite – the wife has a better job, and the husband stays home to take care of the kids, yet society still mocks this choice.

In the fashion industry, people don't take men seriously. They think that if a man is into fashion, he's somehow different from women. They assume that men who are into fashion must have different tastes or lifestyles, and that they can't truly understand women's needs. They think that other men are different, and that they can't possibly understand women's needs. This is why people are discriminated against based on where they're from or their gender. Changing this is difficult because society has formed its own set of stereotypes. We've made a lot of progress, especially with women rising to top business positions and becoming CEOs, but change is slow. If we continue at our current pace, women will keep rising to the top, and people will start to accept this. Similarly, men staying home to take care of the kids is becoming more accepted because people are starting to realize that women might have better jobs. People in the fashion industry are also starting to realize that people's needs might not be what they think they are. So, we need to promote the qualities of people who are often discriminated against without being too pushy. If you try to force it, people will resist. If we're doing everything we can already, we don't need to do anything else because if we do it too quickly, people will resist the change. We've made a lot of progress, and change takes time.

It's also possible that our society will discriminate against you because of where you're from or your gender. For example, if you're from a rural area and your grammar isn't great, but you're extremely intelligent, and you work your way up to be a CEO, other men might look down on you and think, "How do I know you're really saying what you mean if you can't even put together a sentence?" Or if you're intelligent but your grammar isn't great, other men might look down on you. So, our society might discriminate against you because of your gender and where you're from.

I grew up in a Christian family, so homosexuality is a gray area for me. 
Because I have many gay friends, I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, but I believe it should be legalized. 
I don't think it should be a national issue. 
However, I think it should be up to each state to decide rather than the president.

A lot of states are democratic and a lot of states are republican. 
Obviously, democratic states will be in favor of gay marriage. 
If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. 
I don't think you should disagree with the state's decision to legalize gay marriage, as you chose to live there.

I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I believe it should be legalized based on each state's discretion.
